comments.body: When do we expect this to fail?

> When do we expect this to fail?

I'm not sure. I don't understand why we get into that state on macOS nodes sometimes. Currently my best guess is that a build gets cancelled in the middle of this script, i.e. it has unmounted the partition already but hasn't mounted the new one yet.

Under that assumption, this could happen on Linux too.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +122,126 @@            kill -s KILL $pid
        done
        if mount -l | grep $mount_point; then
            umount $mount_point
        fi

comments.body: What happens if there are no PIDs?
`for` doesn't run if the list to run over is empty, like in most languages.

diffHunk:

    if [ -d "$mount_point" ]; then
        for pid in $(pgrep -a -f bazel | awk '{print $1}'); do
            echo "Killing $pid..."
            kill -s KILL $pid

comments.body: I didn't know you could just mount directories to other places like this, but I will take your word for it that it works.
Mounting directories is possible but a bit more complicated; this is mounting files. Specifically, files that have a file system on them.

comments.body: Do you know what we needed icu for before and why we donâ€™t need it anymore? I know GHC uses it but we should get that from nix.

I was not very satisfied with my answer here so I dug a little bit more. Unfortunately that list of dependencies has been added in one chunk with no explanation and nobody asking any question about it, back in #230. Googling for that specific list of dependencies seem to bring up mostly DotNetCore-related hits, so my best guess at this point is that these were the dependencies needed to get the Azure agent working. (It's written in C#.)

Note that I've removed the `libicu55` one because it was causing a problem (not found anymore), i.e. I have not double-checked that the other ones are still necessary.
